results.title: The Potential Therapeutic Application of Simvastatin for Brain Complications and Mechanisms of Action
results.text_hl: Recent studies have suggested that @<m>CHEMICAL_Simvastatin</m> @CHEMICAL_MESH:D019821 @@@simvastatin@@@ could be a promising therapeutic option for different @DISEASE_Brain_Diseases @DISEASE_MESH:D001927 @@@brain complications@@@ and diseases ranging from @DISEASE_Brain_Neoplasms @DISEASE_MESH:D001932 @@@brain tumors@@@ (i.e., @DISEASE_Medulloblastoma @DISEASE_MESH:D008527 @@@medulloblastoma@@@ and @DISEASE_Glioblastoma @DISEASE_MESH:D005909 @@@glioblastoma@@@) to @DISEASE_Neurologic_Manifestations @DISEASE_MESH:D009461 @@@neurological disorders@@@ (i.e., @DISEASE_Alzheimer_Disease @DISEASE_MESH:D000544 @@@Alzheimer's disease@@@, @DISEASE_Parkinson_Disease @DISEASE_MESH:D010300 @@@Parkinson's disease@@@, and @<m>DISEASE_Huntington_Disease</m> @DISEASE_MESH:D006816 @@@Huntington's disease@@@).

citations.NLM: Vuu YM, Kadar Shahib A, Rastegar M. The Potential Therapeutic Application of Simvastatin for Brain Complications and Mechanisms of Action Pharmaceuticals (Basel). 2023 Jun 22;16(7):. PMID: 37513826
citations.BibTeX: @article{37513826, title={The Potential Therapeutic Application of Simvastatin for Brain Complications and Mechanisms of Action}, author={Vuu YM and Kadar Shahib A and Rastegar M}, journal={Pharmaceuticals (Basel)}, volume={16}, number={7}}

results.title: Altered cholesterol homeostasis contributes to enhanced excitotoxicity in Huntington's disease.
results.text_hl: Administration of drugs that recover this effect, such as @<m>CHEMICAL_Simvastatin</m> @CHEMICAL_MESH:D019821 @@@simvastatin@@@ could be beneficial for the treatment of @<m>DISEASE_Huntington_Disease</m> @DISEASE_MESH:D006816 @@@HD@@@.

citations.NLM: del Toro D, Xifró X, Pol A, Humbert S, Saudou F, Canals JM, Alberch J. Altered cholesterol homeostasis contributes to enhanced excitotoxicity in Huntington's disease. J Neurochem. 2010 Oct;115(1):153-67. PMID: 20663016
citations.BibTeX: @article{20663016, title={Altered cholesterol homeostasis contributes to enhanced excitotoxicity in Huntington's disease.}, author={del Toro D and Xifró X and Pol A and Humbert S and Saudou F and Canals JM and Alberch J}, journal={J Neurochem}, volume={115}, number={1}, pages={153-67}}

results.title: C-reactive protein as a cardiovascular risk factor and its therapeutic implications in end-stage renal disease patients.
results.text_hl: We found that @CHEMICAL_Aspirin @CHEMICAL_MESH:D001241 @@@aspirin@@@ 200 mg daily for 8 weeks induce no significant changes of the @GENE_CRP @GENE_1401 @@@CRP@@@ levels in @DISEASE_Peritonitis @DISEASE_MESH:D010538 @@@PD@@@ @SPECIES_9606 @@@patients@@@ (0.22 vs. 0.18 mg/dL, p > 0.05). However, 62 @<m>DISEASE_Huntington_Disease</m> @DISEASE_MESH:D006816 @@@HD@@@ @SPECIES_9606 @@@patients@@@ were randomly assigned to treatment group (@<m>CHEMICAL_Simvastatin</m> @CHEMICAL_MESH:D019821 @@@simvastatin@@@ 20 mg/day) and control group.

citations.NLM: Park JS, Kim SB. C-reactive protein as a cardiovascular risk factor and its therapeutic implications in end-stage renal disease patients. Nephrology (Carlton). 2003 Oct;8 Suppl():S40-4. PMID: 15012690
citations.BibTeX: @article{15012690, title={C-reactive protein as a cardiovascular risk factor and its therapeutic implications in end-stage renal disease patients.}, author={Park JS and Kim SB}, journal={Nephrology (Carlton)}, volume={8 Suppl}, pages={S40-4}}
